content.content:
Accomplishment statements are the foundation of a strong resume. 

Under each of your previous jobs, you’ll include a brief description of your role and responsibilities. To catch the attention of recruiters, turn these descriptions into statements that emphasize your impact and achievements.

content.heading: Turning a job responsibility into an accomplishment statement
content.subheading: Here’s an example of the difference between a basic job responsibility and a strong accomplishment statement:
items: Accomplishment statement: “Trained more than 20 employees in one year, resulting in faster service and increased customer satisfaction.”

content.content: In this activity, you’ll have a chance to practice writing your own statements.

items: Include at least 2 bullet points with accomplishment statements under each job experience.
Use keywords from job postings. Pay attention to what recruiters are looking for in job applicants, and work these into your statements.
Use strong action words. Start each accomplishment with a strong verb and end with a positive outcome.

Check your verb tense. Use present tense verbs for current jobs and past tense verbs for previous jobs. For example, in your current job, you “work on a team of 6” and in your last job, you “worked on a team of 3.”
Include numbers. When you can, back up your accomplishments with numbers. For example, how big was the budget you managed? How many customers did you help in a month?

content.content: If you’re light on job experience, remember that volunteering counts, too. You can add volunteer-related accomplishment statements under work experience or in a separate section.

content.heading: Accomplishment statements from a waiter’s resume (Source: Monster.com)
items: Thrived within high-volume environments, serving up to 275 guests per shift.
Routinely ranked in the top 3 amongst all wait staff at multiple venues for the highest ticket averages.
Upsold customers effectively (e.g., premium bar brands, appetizers and desserts) and optimized table-turns; outperformed wait staff average sales by up to 15%.

content.heading: Accomplishment statements from a bank teller’s resume (Source: Monster.com)
items: Build rapport with customers, displaying friendly, attentive service in all interactions.
Educate customers on online service offerings and mobile apps. Help account holders access technology to enhance banking convenience via multiple self-service channels.
Earned “Employee Ace” award for going above and beyond in assisting teammates and customers.

content.content: Take a few minutes and jot down your ideas for each of these prompts. Don’t overthink it — you’ll have a chance to edit in the last section.

questions.title: Here are up to 4 current or previous jobs I want to start with:

For each of these jobs, here’s how I contributed: 
(Start with an action word like led, launched, managed, trained, coordinated, etc.)

For each of these jobs, here’s at least one of my accomplishments: 
(Start with an action word like won, earned, ranked, etc.)

This is the impact I had in each role: 
(Start with an action word like increased, reduced, streamlined, launched, organized, etc.)
Now use your work above to draft at least 2 accomplishment statements for each of the jobs:
